column1: Mercury is the smallest and innermost planet in the Solar System. Its orbital period (about 88 Earth days) is less than any other planet in the Solar System. Seen from Earth
column2: it appears to move around its orbit in about 116 days. It has no known natural satellites. It is named after the Roman deity Mercury
column3: the messenger to the gods.Partly because it has almost no atmosphere to retain heat
column4: Mercury's surface temperature varies diurnally more than any other planet in the Solar System
column5: ranging from 100 K (-173 °C; -280 °F) at night to 700 K (427 °C; 800 °F) during the day in some equatorial regions. The poles are constantly below 180 K (-93 °C; -136 °F). Mercury's axis has the smallest tilt of any of the Solar System's planets (about 1/30 of a degree)
column6: and its orbital eccentricity is the largest of all known planets in the Solar System.
